alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. You know, 1 of the best things that I do is what we call fromage 4, strong cheese. This is a recipe inspired by my father. He used to do that many, many years ago. At that time, we didn't have food processor, anything. So he used to get leftover cheese, from hard cheese to goat cheese to whatever, put them with a bit of white wine and some bouillon or some soup, and put them in a jar and let it fermentate in the cellar. Then you mash it up into a puree. And that's what we call the fromage 4. So that's what I do here. A lot of people throw cheese out. Look at all that area of cheese. I went through all my refrigerator here, freezer. So usually I would start with the hard cheese to do in there. So see what it looks like. You know, you may have to trim it like here. Maybe I'll trim a little bit of the outside here. But I mean, even if there is a bit of mold, you know, cheese, especially like blue cheese, is what it is, you know, mold. So it's fine. So here, I will cut it into pieces like this. I have that piece of Swiss cheese here. Maybe I'll take this out of it. Okay. I have a mimolette here. Mimolette is really hard. So I'm gonna trim that skin on the other side. And of course, the recipe that I am doing will never be the recipe that you do. It's never the same because depending what's left over. And what you have to look at, look how much of the hard cheese you have, how much of the soft cheese that you have. Because if not, you may even add a little bit of cream cheese, or maybe a couple of tablespoons of sour cream, or something like that to soften the thing. Although we are going to put white wine in it. So I have a piece of Saint-Albre here. This is a pretty strong cheese. And I'm saying I'm trying the outside a little bit. That's a bit strong. I have A piece of blue cheese here. I think this 1 is Roquefort. I'm creaming the outside. This 1, maybe a little bit here. This is like a gorgonzola, so it's a much softer cheese. I have some feta cheese here, as you can see. I have a little piece of camembert. Well, I can even leave the rind in it. If the rind is not damaged, it's fine. And here, I kind of sample, which is a very strong cheese where I'm going to trim that also. So this is my soft cheese. I am going to start. Okay, I have a pound of cheese altogether here. Oh, and I have a slice here of, you know, the American cheese. That's good. Anything goes. I have like 4 clove of garlic here. I'll crush them a little bit, put them in the food processor. You can have less garlic or more. For me, there is never enough garlic. So I love garlic. Okay. So here I'll start with the garlic. I'm gonna put my hot cheese in there. Well, look, it looks pretty thick still, so I'll put the rest of the wine here. I'm gonna put a lot of pepper that I put in it. Usually you don't need salt because the chili salt is enough, but it's always good to test it. I'm gonna clean that around. There you have a glass of marmalade. You know, I put that on top of soup. I put it in pasta. I put it in gratin. Gratin dish goes very, very well with it. I put it in gougere, you know, the little cream puff dough that you do, the little cream puff dough that you do with cheese in it. As you see, Quite a lot of fromage fort. The best way, usually the way we use it is just like this, on toast, and that's how I like it. Just like this. Sometime we put it in the oven to brown it. Under the broiler. It's interesting because when you put it into the oven, it get milder that when you have it untoasted. And this is going to take a couple of minutes under the broiler. A little container for me. To freeze it. And I think I'll keep this 1 in the refrigerator to use it the next couple of days. And here it is, beautifully golden. And as I say, interestingly enough, this is less strong than this. That's how I like it. And that's how you save morel. Use your leftover cheese and do something absolutely delicious with it. Happy cooking. ♪♪

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. You know, 1 of the best things that I do is what we call fromage 4, strong cheese. This is a recipe inspired by my father. He used to do that many, many years ago. At that time, we didn't have food processor, anything.

So he used to get leftover cheese, from hard cheese to goat cheese to whatever, put them with a bit of white wine and some bouillon or some soup, and put them in a jar and let it fermentate in the cellar. Then you mash it up into a puree. And that's what we call the fromage 4. So that's what I do here. A lot of people throw cheese out.

Look at all that area of cheese. I went through all my refrigerator here, freezer. So usually I would start with the hard cheese to do in there. So see what it looks like. You know, you may have to trim it like here.

Maybe I'll trim a little bit of the outside here. But I mean, even if there is a bit of mold, you know, cheese, especially like blue cheese, is what it is, you know, mold. So it's fine. So here, I will cut it into pieces like this. I have that piece of Swiss cheese here.

Maybe I'll take this out of it. Okay. I have a mimolette here. Mimolette is really hard. So I'm gonna trim that skin on the other side.

And of course, the recipe that I am doing will never be the recipe that you do. It's never the same because depending what's left over. And what you have to look at, look how much of the hard cheese you have, how much of the soft cheese that you have. Because if not, you may even add a little bit of cream cheese, or maybe a couple of tablespoons of sour cream, or something like that to soften the thing. Although we are going to put white wine in it.

So I have a piece of Saint-Albre here. This is a pretty strong cheese. And I'm saying I'm trying the outside a little bit. That's a bit strong. I have A piece of blue cheese here.

I think this 1 is Roquefort. I'm creaming the outside. This 1, maybe a little bit here. This is like a gorgonzola, so it's a much softer cheese. I have some feta cheese here, as you can see.

I have a little piece of camembert. Well, I can even leave the rind in it. If the rind is not damaged, it's fine. And here, I kind of sample, which is a very strong cheese where I'm going to trim that also. So this is my soft cheese.

I am going to start. Okay, I have a pound of cheese altogether here. Oh, and I have a slice here of, you know, the American cheese. That's good. Anything goes.

I have like 4 clove of garlic here. I'll crush them a little bit, put them in the food processor. You can have less garlic or more. For me, there is never enough garlic. So I love garlic.

Okay. So here I'll start with the garlic. I'm gonna put my hot cheese in there. Well, look, it looks pretty thick still, so I'll put the rest of the wine here. I'm gonna put a lot of pepper that I put in it.

Usually you don't need salt because the chili salt is enough, but it's always good to test it. I'm gonna clean that around. There you have a glass of marmalade. You know, I put that on top of soup. I put it in pasta.

I put it in gratin. Gratin dish goes very, very well with it. I put it in gougere, you know, the little cream puff dough that you do, the little cream puff dough that you do with cheese in it. As you see, Quite a lot of fromage fort. The best way, usually the way we use it is just like this, on toast, and that's how I like it.

Just like this. Sometime we put it in the oven to brown it. Under the broiler. It's interesting because when you put it into the oven, it get milder that when you have it untoasted. And this is going to take a couple of minutes under the broiler.

A little container for me. To freeze it. And I think I'll keep this 1 in the refrigerator to use it the next couple of days. And here it is, beautifully golden. And as I say, interestingly enough, this is less strong than this.

That's how I like it. And that's how you save morel. Use your leftover cheese and do something absolutely delicious with it. Happy cooking. ♪♪

This is a recipe inspired by my father.
He used to do that many, many years ago.
At that time, we didn't have food processor, anything.

So he used to get leftover cheese, from hard cheese to goat cheese to whatever, put them with a bit of white wine and some bouillon or some soup, and put them in a jar and let it fermentate in the cellar.
Then you mash it up into a puree.
And that's what we call the fromage 4.
So that's what I do here.
A lot of people throw cheese out.
Look at all that area of cheese.
I went through all my refrigerator here, freezer.
So usually I would start with the hard cheese to do in there.
So see what it looks like.
You know, you may have to trim it like here.
Maybe I'll trim a little bit of the outside here.
But I mean, even if there is a bit of mold, you know, cheese, especially like blue cheese, is what it is, you know, mold.
So it's fine.
So here, I will cut it into pieces like this.
I have that piece of Swiss cheese here.
Maybe I'll take this out of it.
Okay.
I have a mimolette here.
Mimolette is really hard.
So I'm gonna trim that skin on the other side.
And of course, the recipe that I am doing will never be the recipe that you do.
It's never the same because depending what's left over.
And what you have to look at, look how much of the hard cheese you have, how much of the soft cheese that you have.
Because if not, you may even add a little bit of cream cheese, or maybe a couple of tablespoons of sour cream, or something like that to soften the thing.
Although we are going to put white wine in it.
So I have a piece of Saint-Albre here.
This is a pretty strong cheese.

I have a little piece of camembert.
Well, I can even leave the rind in it.

And here, I kind of sample, which is a very strong cheese where I'm going to trim that also.
So this is my soft cheese.
I am going to start.

Oh, and I have a slice here of, you know, the American cheese.
That's good.

I have like 4 clove of garlic here.
I'll crush them a little bit, put them in the food processor.
You can have less garlic or more.
For me, there is never enough garlic.
So I love garlic.

I put it in gougere, you know, the little cream puff dough that you do, the little cream puff dough that you do with cheese in it.
As you see, Quite a lot of fromage fort.
The best way, usually the way we use it is just like this, on toast, and that's how I like it.
Just like this.
Sometime we put it in the oven to brown it.
Under the broiler.
It's interesting because when you put it into the oven, it get milder that when you have it untoasted.
And this is going to take a couple of minutes under the broiler.
A little container for me.
To freeze it.
And I think I'll keep this 1 in the refrigerator to use it the next couple of days.
And here it is, beautifully golden.
And as I say, interestingly enough, this is less strong than this.

And that's how you save morel.
Use your leftover cheese and do something absolutely delicious with it.
